definition: to accumulate over a long period of time
abbr. for 日本[Ri4 ben3], Japan
sun/day/date, day of the month

to amass/to accumulate/to store/measured quantity (such as area of volume)/product (the result of multiplication)/to integrate (math.)/to solve (or integrate) an ordinary differential equation (math.)/old/long-standing
moon/month/monthly/CL:個|个[ge4],輪|轮[lun2]
tired/weary/to strain/to wear out/to work hard
to accumulate/to involve or implicate (Taiwan pr. [lei4])/continuous/repeated

sentences.english: Most of what I write starts off as junk, then it becomes piles of junk.
sentences.chinese: 大部分我自己寫下的想法起初都是垃圾，日積月累。

sentences.english: Cumulatively, the Premier League has the highest debt, followed by the Spanish Primera and then the Serie A.
sentences.chinese: 日積月累，英超有着最高的負債，然後是西甲和意甲。

sentences.english: Over time to pay long-term efforts.
sentences.chinese: 要日積月累，付出長期的努力。

sentences.english: Down over time will also increase their knowledge of English.
sentences.chinese: 日積月累下來自身的英語知識也會提高。

sentences.english: Over time, cumulatively , between you and his feelings will be faded.
sentences.chinese: 時間久了，日積月累，你和他之間的感情也就淡了。

sentences.english: Little grains of sand can add up to a mountain over time.
sentences.chinese: 日積月累，要相信細沙也可以堆積成山。

sentences.english: Over time, your gait will become more efficient.
sentences.chinese: 日積月累，你的步法將越來越有效率。

sentences.english: Many a little makes a mickle. Over time, a long levee of logs was thus formed.
sentences.chinese: 日積月累，積少成多，就形成了現在的這條枯木長堤。

definition: to guide patiently and systematically (idiom)
for years/over the years
(idiom) (of a good outcome) unanticipated/serendipitous/fortuitous
after hard work and numerous revisions (idiom)/the vicissitudes of life
pavilion in the air (idiom); unrealistic Utopian construction/castles in Spain/imaginary future plans
diligent and attentive/assiduous/sincere
to exhaust one's thoughts and ingenuity (idiom); to think sth through thoroughly/to rack one's brains/to leave no stone unturned
to bury oneself in work (idiom); to be engrossed in work/to make an all-out effort/up to the neck in work
when you teach someone, both teacher and student will benefit
It takes ten years to nurture a tree, but a hundred years to train a man (idiom)/fig. a good education program takes a long time to develop/cf. 十年樹木，百年樹人|十年树木，百年树人
different routes to the same destination (idiom); fig. different means of achieve the same end
scholastic attainments
priceless treasure
to waste
initiative/active role
to neglect sleep and forget about food (idiom)/to skip one's sleep and meals/to be completely wrapped up in one's work
